channel.title: U.S. foreign policy: Demands of the next decade
channel.description:
On the occasion of its 50th anniversary, the Foreign Policy Association of the United States organized a traveling conference based on the theme "demands of the next decade." This is a series of recorded speeches from a 1968 Portland, Oregon, conference sponsored by the FPA, the World Affairs Council of Oregon, and Time Magazine.

An online collection of early educational public radio content from the National Association of Educational Broadcasters (NAEB).

image.title: U.S. foreign policy: Demands of the next decade

item.title: Within the World Economy, reel 1
item.description: Richard Gardner, Columbia University law professor and senior adviser to U.N. ambassador Arthur Goldberg, shares his view of the upcoming economic challenges to the American people in the next 10 years: trade, aid to less developed countries, and the international monetary situation.
item.dc:creator: Oregon State University
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Within the Western Alliance, reel 1
item.description: ABC News commentator Joseph C. Harsch discusses NATO and other western alliances.
item.dc:creator: Oregon State University
item.dc:subject: United States--Military relations--Europe

item.title: Projections: Asia, reel 2
item.description: Harold Isaacs, journalist and professor of political science at MIT, traces the historical and cultural roots of Chinese and communist expansionism in Southeast Asia.
item.dc:creator: Oregon State University
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Demands of the Next Decade
item.description: [NOTE: reel 2 available only] Demands of the Next Decade. Speakers from previous programs come together to review the spectrum of U.S. foreign policy.
item.dc:creator: Oregon State University
item.dc:subject: United States--Foreign relations--20th century

item.title: Within the World Economy, reel 2
item.description: Richard Gardner, Columbia University law professor and senior adviser to U.N. ambassador Arthur Goldberg, shares his view of the upcoming economic challenges to the American people in the next 10 years: trade, aid to less developed countries, and the international monetary situation.
item.dc:creator: Oregon State University
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Projections: Africa, reel 2
item.description: [NOTE: reel 2 available only] Projections: Africa. Arnold Rivkin, an expert on African development at the World Bank, looks at Africa policy today and in the next ten years.
item.dc:creator: Oregon State University
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Projections: Asia, reel 1
item.description: Harold Isaacs, journalist and professor of political science at MIT, traces the historical and cultural roots of Chinese and communist expansionism in Southeast Asia.
item.dc:creator: Oregon State University
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Projections: Latin America, reel 2
item.description: [NOTE: reel 2 available only]: Projections: Latin America. Teodoro Moscoso, Alliance for Progress, and former ambassador to Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Oregon State University
item.dc:subject: United States--Foreign relations--Latin America

item.title: Within the Communist World, reel 2
item.description: This program features a lecture by Philip E. Mosley, director of the European Institute at Columbia University, on the current economic, social, political, and governmental status of the Soviet Union and China as well as their influence in--and threat to--the rest of the world.
item.dc:creator: Oregon State University
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Within the Communist World, reel 1
item.description: This program features a lecture by Philip E. Mosley, director of the European Institute at Columbia University, on the current economic, social, political, and governmental status of the Soviet Union and China as well as their influence in--and threat to--the rest of the world.
item.dc:creator: Oregon State University
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.dc:creator: Oregon State University
item.dc:subject: United States--Military relations--Europe
